Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, blueprints spread out before me, my laptop pinging with reminders from the office. As an architect, I was expected to keep projects on track, but lately, I’d been reviewing timelines more casually, trusting my team to handle the details. My mind, though, was elsewhere—on the promise I’d made to my stepson. He’d been counting down the days to his birthday, certain I’d buy him the Nintendo he’d wanted for months. My partner reminded me how important it was to keep promises, especially as a step-parent trying to build trust. But the cost gnawed at me. We’d been tight on money, and I felt the weight of ensuring our family’s financial stability. If I bought the Nintendo, I’d have to cut back somewhere else. If I didn’t, I’d risk disappointing him and undermining my role in his life. My phone buzzed again—another project update. I stared at the screen, torn between the demands of my job and the expectations at home, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
